document_title: Dilated cardiomyopathy: Causes, signs, treatment and prevention
subsection_content:
MSc. Huynh Thanh Kieu said that there are no measures to help prevent hereditary cardiomyopathy. However, you can reduce your risk of conditions that can lead to cardiomyopathy, such as coronary artery disease, hypertension and heart attack, by making lifestyle changes: (5)
1. Have a healthy diet
A heart-healthy diet includes:
A variety of fruits, vegetables and grains. Of these, half of the grains should come from whole grain products such as brown rice, oats, corn, etc.; Choose foods low in saturated fat and trans fat. Healthy options include lean meat, skinless poultry, non-fried fish, legumes (soybeans, peanuts, black beans, white beans…) as well as fat-free or low-fat milk and dairy products. fat.; Season with a little salt when preparing food. Consuming a lot of salt can increase the risk of high blood pressure, thereby increasing the likelihood of cardiomyopathy.; Prioritize foods and drinks low in sugar; Limit alcohol intake.; Maintain a stable weight by ensuring your daily calorie intake is no higher than your calorie expenditure.
Building a menu with lots of fruits and vegetables, whole grains, and limiting cholesterol will help improve heart health.
2. Have an active lifestyle every day
Even if you have heart disease, you should not sit still but be physically active as much as possible. Suitable exercises for you are slow walking, swimming, slow cycling, badminton... If you want to increase exercise intensity or play sports that require more exertion, you need to consult your doctor. especially when you are taking medication, have some health problems or experience symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness...
See more: How long can you live with dilated cardiomyopathy and is it dangerous?
3. Build a scientific living regime
MSc. Huynh Thanh Kieu emphasized that with appropriate diet and exercise, the risk of disease will be reduced if you have a scientific lifestyle:
Do not smoke (both direct smoking and passive smoke); Lose weight if you have BMI > 23; Avoid alcohol and drugs; Sleep at least 7-8 hours/day; Reduce work pressure, take time to rest and relax; Control stress, avoid being stressed for long periods of time; Treatment of accompanying diseases, such as diabetes, dyslipidemia, hypertension...; Periodic health examination; Take the correct dosage according to your doctor's instructions.
People with dilated cardiomyopathy need regular check-ups as prescribed by their doctor.
Cardiovascular Center, Tam Anh General Hospital brings together a team of experienced experts and a modern, advanced machinery system to help support doctors in diagnosing and providing the best treatment regimen for patients. patient. The center regularly updates modern methods in diagnosing and treating cardiomyopathy such as dilated cardiomyopathy, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, restrictive myocardium, myocardial ischemia... and other cardiovascular diseases. such as hypertension, arrhythmia, coronary artery disease, valvular heart disease, congenital heart disease...
In addition, the Cardiovascular Center of Tam Anh General Hospital also has close coordination with the Diagnostic Imaging Center, Laboratory Center, Neonatal Center, Kidney and Urology Center, and Obstetrics and Gynecology Center. Department, Department of Pediatrics... helps improve the effectiveness of diagnosis and treatment for patients with many comorbidities.
Dilated cardiomyopathy may cause no symptoms in some people in the early stages, but can be life-threatening in its later stages. Therefore, early detection and timely and correct treatment of the disease play a very important role. In addition, adhering to a scientific diet, regular exercise, and a healthy lifestyle are effective measures in improving symptoms and preventing dangerous complications of the disease.
